Test Description: Cluster name should be max 63 characters

Test Description: Tested as part of Create

Create network pod with replication controller. Shut down node. Make sure of following:
- Network Reservations are reflected correctly
- Pod restarts as expected
- QoS is honoured
Check that you are able to create volumes and pods when the node joins back. Master doesn't change.
Check that another node becomes master
Ensure cluster stays up without master changing
Make a node unhealthy*/NotReady and check if cluster status reflects that
Expected Behaviour: May be by shutting down vf0, ifconfig down 192.168.100.2

Test Description: Kill host processes and test they restart without impact
Expected Behaviour: kill processes like armada, convoy, bosun, etc

Test Description: Master fail over should happen
Flap the mgmt interface on master (VIP usually disappears)
Expected Behaviour:
ifconfig down virtual ip, when up vip should be pingable.
ifconfig ens255f1:1 down
ifconfig ens255f1:1 172.16.19.50
Notes / Detailed Description:
If we down the interface
 - VIP is not pingable
 - cluster become inaccessibe 
up the interface
  -VIP is pingable
  - now cluster is accessible

Test Description:
Create a cluster. 
Reboot a node.
Check whether node comes in ready state.
Cluster destroy When volumes are in attached state
Try to remove quorum node from cluster using dctl cluster remove node.
Expected Behaviour: dctl cluster remove <node-name> shouldn't allow removal of quorum node

Test Description:
Destroy the cluster when a member node is not available, the node can contain
stale configuration information
Notes / Detailed Description:
On the node, clean the node configuration by running the following command:
sudo /usr/local/bin/diamanti-node-cleanup.sh

Test Description: Create cluster with wrong svlan. Update svlan using dctl configure. cluster status should reflect that and remote and mirrored storage should start working
Create cluster with svlan=0. Remote and mirrored storage should not work

Create a static endpoint. Launch KVM utilizing the static endpoint. Once VM is up and running, do a shutdown -h now in the VM. POD should go into the completed state. Delete node that pod was on from the cluster. After node is removed from cluster, its static endpoint should get deleted.
Create one node cluster. See that the node is in Good state and all resources (vnics, storage, etc) are seen as expected
Create cluster with only one etcd node and multiple non-etcd nodes.

Create a local volume and attach it to a pod. Try to remove the node from cluster where pod exists. Should fail. Delete the pod. After the volume moves to Available state, remove the node. Node removal should be allowed. Add the node back to the cluster. Node should join back the cluster and volume should move to Available state. Create a pod again. Volume should get attached and pod should start running
Create a volume on node A and attach it to a pod on node B. Try to remove the node B from cluster. Should fail.

Create 8 volumes on nodes (local, remote, mirrored). Attach them to a node. Run fio job on all the volumes. Calculate sha512sum for all the volumes and plexes. Detach volumes. Remove one of the nodes from the cluster such that it contains plexes of local, remote and mirrored volumes. Add the node back to cluster. Re-attach all the volumes. Calculate sha512sum of all volumes. They should match with the output taken before removing node. 
Detach the volumes again. Remove the same node again from cluster. Reboot the node. Add the node back to cluster. Re-attach the volumes. Calculate sha512sum of all volumes. They should match again. 
Increase the mirror count of local and remote volumes to 3. Allow the plexes to resync. Calculate sha512sum of these volumes. They should match.

Create a volume on node A and attach it to a pod on node B. Try to remove the node A from cluster. Should fail. Delete the pod. After the volume moves to Available state, remove the node A. Node removal should be allowed. Add back the node A to cluster. Node should join back the cluster and volume should move to Available state. Create a pod again on node B. Volume should get attached and pod should start running

Create a 3 way mirrored volume using nodes A,B,C. Attach it to a pod on node A. Try removing the node B from cluster. It should get removed.
Add node B back to the cluster. The plex should get attached and Resync should trigger and the plex should come back to InSync state

Create a 3 way mirrored volume using nodes A,B,C. Attach it to a pod on node A. Remove node B from cluster. Node will get removed. Delete the pod. Volume should move to Available state. Pod should get deleted successfully.
Re-create the pod again. Volume should get attached and Pod should go into Running state.

Create a 3 way mirrored volume using nodes A,B,C. Attach it to a pod on node A. Remove node B from cluster. Node will get removed.
Delete the plex that was residing on the node B. Plex should be deleted successfully. Add the node B back to the cluster. The node will remain in Pending state. Node will remain in Pending state as node discovery detects the plex on the node but the same plex doesn’t exist in the cluster anymore.

Create a 3 way mirrored volume using nodes A,B,C. Attach it to a pod on node A. Remove node B from cluster. Node will get removed.
Delete the plex that was residing on the node B. Plex should be deleted successfully. Run "sputil -ta" command on embedded side of node B. Reboot the node B. Now add the nodeB to cluster. The nodeB should return to Good state.

Create a 3 way mirrored volume using nodes A,B,C. Attach it to a pod on node A. Remove node B from cluster. Node will get removed.
Run "sputil -ta" command on embedded side of node B. Reboot the node B. Now add the nodeB to cluster. The nodeB should return to Good state
Create a pod with dynamic endpoint on nodeA. Remove nodeA. What is expected? Add nodeA back to cluster. What is expected?
Create a pod with static endpoint on nodeA. Remove nodeA. What is expected? Add nodeA back to cluster. What is expected?
Create cluster with SVLAN = 0
Notes / Detailed Description: This is equivalent to remote storage disabled

Test Description: Create cluster with SVLAN = Network VLAN, say blue. Run remote and mirrored fio pods and iperf pods. If switch config allows same VLAN for both storage and network then remote storage pod as well as network pod should be running with traffic on same VLAN
Notes / Detailed Description: When customer has a single VLAN available for PoC environment or even perhaps production

Test Description: Create cluster with SVLAN = Network VLAN, say blue. Run remote and mirrored fio pods and iperf pods. If switch config disallows same VLAN for both storage and network then remote storage pod should not be running with traffic.
Create cluster with multiple Network VLANs (say 64 VLANs) and few pods on each VLAN.
Cluster with VLAN[s], SVLAN at multiple random numbers (cover 4044+ range also).
Create cluster with docker disable and verify all pods are in running state

dctl login with --proxy option. Check whether all dctl and kubectl calls are going to proxy server. Make sure that kubectl following commands work:
kubectl logs -f, attach, exec, proxy, cp, port-forward)

dctl login with --insecure. Check whether all dctl and kubectl calls are non-secure i.e not using certs. Make sure that kubectl following commands work:
kubectl logs -f, attach, exec, proxy, cp, port-forward)
Notes / Detailed Description:
How to ensure insecure option works?
Ans:- Create cluster, generate cluster with 10 min expirary time. 
After 10 min dctl commands should fail. Then login with --insecure option. Now dctl commands should work.

Test Description:
dctl login with --insecure-k8s. Check whether only kubectl calls are non-secure i.e not using certs but dctl calls are secure (using certs). Make sure that kubectl following commands work:
kubectl logs -f, attach, exec, proxy, cp, port-forward)

dctl login with --proxy --insecure option. Check whether all dctl and kubectl calls are going to proxy server but they are not secure. Make sure that kubectl following commands work:
kubectl logs -f, attach, exec, proxy, cp, port-forward)

dctl login with --proxy --insecure-k8s option. Check whether all dctl and kubectl calls are going to proxy server but they are not secure. Make sure that kubectl following commands work:
kubectl logs -f, attach, exec, proxy, cp, port-forward)

Run pods and delete them. Create race condition
1. Run 60 iperf pods and start deleting them at 0th seconds after pod creation.
2. Run 60 iperf pods and start deleting them at 30th seconds after pod creation
3. Run 60 iperf pods and start deleting them at 60th seconds after pod creation
4. Run 60 iperf pods and start deleting them at 90th seconds after pod creation
Notes / Detailed Description:
Check if network,vnic,endpoint resources are cleaned-up after every deletion


ETCDCTL_API=3 etcdctl get --endpoints=appserv56:2379 --prefix /dw/reservations/default/

Test Description:
Run volumes and delete them. Create race condition
1. Create 60 volumes and start deleting them at 0th seconds after volume creation
2. Create 60 volumes and start deleting them at 30th seconds after volume creation
3. Create 60 volumes and start deleting them at 60th seconds after volume creation
4. Create 60 volumes and start deleting them at 90th seconds after volume creation
Expected Behaviour:
#!/bin/bash

wait_time=0
for x in {1..4}
do
        for y in {1..60}
        do
                dctl volume create test-vol"$y"-itr"$x"
        done
        sleep "$wait_time"
        wait_time=`expr $wait_time + 30`
        dctl volume list | awk '{print $1}' | xargs -i dctl volume delete {} -y
done
Notes / Detailed Description:
Check if network,vnic,endpoint resources are cleaned-up after every deletion


ETCDCTL_API=3 etcdctl get --endpoints=appserv56:2379 --prefix /dw/reservations/default/
